title: Forest of Argonne
text:
The Forest of Argonne () is a long strip of mountainous and wild woodland in northeastern <a href="France">France</a>, approximately east of <a href="Paris">Paris</a>. The forest measures roughly 40 miles long and 10 miles wide filled with many small hills and deep valleys formed by water run-off from the <a href="Aire%20River%20%28France%29">Aire</a> and <a href="Aisne%20%28river%29">Aisne</a> rivers rarely exceeding more than 650 feet in elevation. Post <a href="World%20War%20I">World War l</a> the landscape of the forest was forever changed, <a href="trench%20warfare">trench warfare</a> lead to parts of the forest being riddled with deep man-made trenches along with craters from explosives. The forest is bordered by the Meuse River on the west and rolling farmland and creeks to the east. The forest is largely <a href="oak">oak</a>, <a href="chestnut">chestnut</a>, and <a href="pine">pine</a> trees, and <a href="fern">fern</a>s cover much of the forest floor. Common animal life consists of <a href="wild%20boar">wild boar</a>, <a href="red%20deer">red deer</a>, <a href="roe%20deer">roe deer</a>, <a href="hare">hare</a>s, <a href="rabbit">rabbit</a>s, <a href="fox">fox</a>es, <a href="wildcat">wildcat</a>, and <a href="brown%20bear">brown bear</a>s.
History.
In 1792, <a href="Charles%20Fran%C3%A7ois%20Dumouriez">Charles François Dumouriez</a> outmaneuvered the invading forces of the <a href="Charles%20William%20Ferdinand%2C%20Duke%20of%20Brunswick">Duke of Brunswick</a> in the forest before the <a href="Battle%20of%20Valmy">Battle of Valmy</a>.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the forest again became the site of intense military action. Bitter fighting between German and Allied units took place here in fall and winter 1914, summer 1915, and fall 1918. During the <a href="Meuse%E2%80%93Argonne%20offensive">Meuse–Argonne offensive</a> (1918), several <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> soldiers earned the <a href="Medal%20of%20Honor">Medal of Honor</a> there, including Colonel <a href="Nelson%20M.%20Holderman">Nelson Miles Holderman</a>, Major <a href="Charles%20White%20Whittlesey">Charles White Whittlesey</a>, Sergeant <a href="Alvin%20York">Alvin C. York</a>, Corporal <a href="Harold%20W.%20Roberts">Harold W. Roberts</a> and <a href="Henry%20Johnson%20%28World%20War%20I%20soldier%29">William Henry Johnson</a> (a.k.a. "Black Death"), most of them part of the "<a href="Lost%20Battalion%20%28World%20War%20I%29">Lost Battalion</a>". The World War I <a href="Meuse-Argonne%20American%20Memorial">Montfaucon American Monument</a> consists of a large <a href="granite">granite</a> <a href="Doric%20column">Doric column</a> surmounted by a statue symbolic of <a href="Liberty">Liberty</a>. The monument is located northwest of <a href="Verdun">Verdun</a>, not far from the <a href="Meuse-Argonne%20American%20Cemetery">Meuse–Argonne American Cemetery and Memorial</a>.
